title: Velvet scoter
text:
The velvet scoter ("Melanitta fusca"), also called a velvet duck, is a large <a href="Merginae">sea duck</a>, which breeds over the far north of <a href="Europe">Europe</a> and the <a href="Palearctic">Palearctic</a> west of the <a href="Yenisey">Yenisey</a> basin. The genus name is derived from <a href="Ancient%20Greek">Ancient Greek</a> "melas" "black" and "netta" "duck". The species name is from the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> "fuscus" "dusky brown".
A small, isolated population nests in eastern <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>. <a href="Stejneger%27s%20scoter">Stejneger's scoter</a> and the <a href="white-winged%20scoter">white-winged scoter</a> are sometimes considered <a href="conspecific">conspecific</a> with the velvet scoter, and its two constituent subspecies are then known as "M. f. stejnegeri" and "M. f. deglandi". Velvet, Stejneger's, and white-winged scoter, along with the <a href="surf%20scoter">surf scoter</a>, are placed in the subgenus "Melanitta", distinct from the subgenus "Oidemia", <a href="black%20scoter">black scoter</a> and <a href="common%20scoter">common scoter</a>s.
It <a href="bird%20migration">winters</a> farther south in <a href="temperate">temperate</a> zones, <a href="Europe">Europe</a> as far south as <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a>, and on the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black</a> and <a href="Caspian%20Sea">Caspian Sea</a>. Small numbers reach <a href="France">France</a> and northern <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. It forms large <a href="Flock%20%28birds%29">flocks</a> on suitable coastal waters. These are tightly packed, and the birds tend to take off together. The species is listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN.
The lined <a href="bird%20nest">nest</a> is built on the ground close to the sea, lakes or rivers, in <a href="woodland">woodland</a> or <a href="tundra">tundra</a>, and typically contains 7–9 <a href="egg%20%28biology%29">egg</a>s. This duck dives for <a href="crustacean">crustacean</a>s and <a href="mollusc">mollusc</a>s.
It is characterised by its bulky shape and large bill. It is the largest scoter at 51–58 cm. The male is all black, except for white around the eye and a white <a href="speculum%20feathers">speculum</a>. It has a bulbous yellow bill with a black base. The females are brown <a href="bird">bird</a>s with two pale patches on each side of the head and white wing patches.
The velvet scoter is one of the species to which the "Agreement on the Conservation of African-Eurasian Migratory Waterbirds" (<a href="AEWA">AEWA</a>) applies.
